comment_text: While lamarkian genetics are not correct in that they prioritize environment and experience over selection and of course know nothing of modern genetics, it is true that through DNA methylation experience can account for some phenotypic variation. Not defending any of the theories or practices presented, just an interesting note I thought.

Science is political due to some non-scientists is high positions who fervently deny empirical observation in favour of an encompassing ideological framework. To disagree with such a framework automatically make one's studies contentious to some degree, even if only perceived to be in opposition. Vavilov was seen as a threat to the inflexible Stalinist dogma because he seemed to disagree with the ideals of Marx despite the real observations of his work.

Science is therefore forced to be political in opposition to the force of anti-intellectualism.

My great-grandfather was a soviet geneticist and Morgan's student. He was against Lysenko and after he wrote an article for an international scientific magazine telling that Lysenko is not a real scientist he was fired and put through sham trials and courts. He had to hide from NKVD in Moscow and died soon of a heart attack. True story. I still have his old microscope.

10:37 "All science is political. Saying you're apolitical means you're for the status quo."

Not gonna lie, this strikes me as an incredibly irresponsible thing to say. Surely this view reduces empiricism to ideology?

If you genuinely believed this, then you would interpret ALL scientific discoveries as 'secretly' political. Thus Giordano Bruno's heliocentric publications were 'secretly' intentional, heretical attacks against the church. By this logic the church may have been justified in publicly burning him alive; he was a dissident after all, since his research was inherently political...

Obviously I flatly disagree with the statement "all science is political." I hope you reconsider this assertion and at least avoid repeating it in future episodes.

Please don't shove Marxism down people's throats, as you tried to do in the video on modern Chinese hisory. It's highly opinionated, not factual to say 'all science is political'. That's binary thinking which is highly associated with incorrect predictions (See Philip Tetlock's work).

There's a bit of a mental gymnastics. Science is not itself political, otherwise it would be all lysenkoist. Science can be used in politics as it can be used for war. But science isn't war and it's also not politics.

??  And what's the likelihood that all those 'smart' scientist were/are Masons???  And like Nasa,  Masons lie.  Ooops.

I don't quite understand what is meant by "all forms of science are political." I get the feeling my definition of political differs from yours. My understanding is that science is apolitical because the process of doing science actively filters out political ideology to keep it from affecting the empirical collection of data. Sure, some people use science to further political goals, but the science itself isn't political. To claim so is like saying cardboard is political because some people make protest signs out of cardboard. (The video hasn't made the precise argument that science is political because politicians use science politically, but some people in the comments have)
